lines.text: I always drink at lunchtime. It helps my imagination.
The secret of a happy life is to know when to stop - and then go that bit further.
When I'm thinking, I get thirsty.
Drink that, Lewis, and loosen some brain cells.
There's always time for one more pint.
Coded messages, murder - right up my street. It's not a bad way to start the day.
I'm old and unmarried, and I don't understand human nature. What does it matter?
[after Morse has been hit on the head]
'Tis not so wide as a church door nor so deep as a river, but 'tis enough.
Ideals come to torment us all at some stage, or at least they should do.
[as Lewis makes a chance remark which unwittingly provides Morse with a major clue]
